case_vignette: a 10-year-old male presents with non-blanchable palpable purple papules on both legs for a week. sore throat preceded the skin lesions. his parents deny any other history of infectious diseases or new medications. the boy complains about abdominal pain and trouble walking. his vitals are stable. physical exam reveals red and swollen ankles on top of palpable purpura on both legs.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have some purple spots on both my legs that I can feel when I touch them, a sore throat, abdominal pain, and my ankles are red, swollen, and it hurts to walk.
How long have you had these symptoms?
I've had these symptoms for about a week.
Do you have any allergies or medical conditions?
No, I don't have any allergies or known medical conditions.
Have you recently started taking any new medications or supplements?
No, I haven't started taking any new medications or supplements.
Is there a history of similar symptoms in your family?
No, there's no history of similar symptoms in my family.
Final Diagnosis: Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP)
